description: A former brick making factory, Evergreen Brick Works is now a place where the world can experience sustainable practices that enable flourishing cities of the future. Evergreen Brick Works connects citizens, business, academia and government to shape our cities for the better. For real. Open daily and year-round, Evergreen Brick Works engages visitors in a full suite of attractions and events including our Saturday Farmers' Market, nature trails for hiking and cycling, site tours, exhibits, conferences, festivals, nature-based camps for youth and a sustainable garden market and eco-store.

reviews.title: We don't really see what the attraction is!
text: There's nothing really here to possibly recommend.  Empty steel overhead canopies when the farmer's market is not on (surely they could set up something mid-week).  And the other building is an empty warehouse.  Lots of cement, very little "brick".  No exhibits or spectacular architecture.  Not enough outdoor seating, nor spread out.  Parking machine did not accept cash or credit card, due July 15, 2024 flood, so had to scan bar code.  Paid $8.33 for 90 minutes parking.  Did they replace accessibility parking with carpool parking?  One plus is the nice view from self-serve restaurant.  Pleasant staff, but woefully understaffed during long weekend, so that was most of our time.  Food prices are fairly high.  Country store has overpriced items, that people really don't need.  Washroom had two out-of-service hand dryers, and unattended.  Disappointing for a place with so much potential.  Misses the mark on many levels.

reviews.title: A haven just outside the city
text: With just a fairly short journey you are out of the city and in this peaceful haven of nature. There are a number of lovely walks and we enjoyed walking along the boardwalk and seeing all the turtles. The cafe served very good lunches and there is a nice garden centre.

reviews.title: Beautiful foliage scene
text: I was recommended to visit Evergreen Brickworks by friends and family when I visited Toronto. Itâ€™s a lovely way to get out of the city and getting a taste of nature without having to go too far. The extended park area allows you to explore far enough that you never really feel that it gets too crowded even on weekends. I went in the end of October and the fall foliage was perfect. There is also the farmers and food market which adds to the element of fun. I would definitely recommend spending a long afternoon here.

reviews.title: Nice for a walk
text: It is a beautiful place to walk or bike around. In winter time they have a lot of winter activities as well.

reviews.title: An oasis in an increasingly busy city of Toronto

reviews.title: Nature walk, farmers market and garden centre
text: We went here on April 30th.

It was the first day they opened the outdoor market. The market is only opened on Saturdays from 9:00am-1:00pm. We got here at 9:30 and the parking lot was almost full. We paid $6 for parking. We went to the market and all the vendors were not there because it was the first day and it was raining. Not a lot of fruits and vegetables in season yet. There is a garden centre on the other side. There is a store that sells artwork, plants, crafts, honey, sauces. Thereâ€™s a cafe in there and you can get a sandwich and coffee. They have lots of nature trails. We didnâ€™t get to do it because it was raining. There is a dog park and bike trails. We actually got to see a beaver in a stream by the entrance. Apparently a 6 inch tooth of a prehistoric beaver was found on the property and you can see it on display in one of the buildings that also has the old machine used in the making of bricks The company was opened for over 100 years. Lots of history here. Itâ€™s a great place to visit on a nice day when you can go on the many nature trails.

reviews.title: Torontoâ€™s Natural Ravines
text: I first visited the Brickworks in 2017 as a spring-time online dating meeting place. Nearly 6 years later, she and I still take regular walks through the old quarry in all seasons. I wrote an article with photos about the history of the Evergreen Brickworks, establishing a nature centre out of dirty industry. Google it on Harrowsmith magazine website. It launched me into a long-term personal photo documentary project about Torontoâ€™s natural ravines with a friend who offers guided walks.

reviews.title: Interesting gardens in historical locale
text: Most Toronto buildings were built with bricks made here. Now has weekend markets, various shops and a nice garden.

reviews.title: Only real farmer's market in Toronto on Saturdays
text: Great place to get local produce in the city.  The selection is more limited than some other cities, but it's great to buy the freshest product direct from the farmer.

reviews.title: Nice place for a summer Saturday
text: This market is really nice for spending a couple of hours with your kids or without.

Many fresh vegetables directly from the farms and dairy and meat products as well. Some nice gardens to walk around and shady places to sit and relax and some cafes for coffee and food. Parking is also close by (fee)

reviews.title: The place to go summer, spring, fall and winter.
text: With farmers' markets every Saturday, there lots of excellent produce to be had. But you won't go hungry, as there are many food food vendors here as well. Sundays are for arts and crafts, with food vendors also present. There are also walking trails in this converted decommissioned clay mine - easy ones for those with limited mobility and steeper ones for the fit :-)

reviews.title: An environmental experience
text: For those travellors interested in exploring how local principalities are solving and helping to restore a new life to exploited and plighted areas into new revitalized centers.The Brick Works is a near perfect solution to reclaiming and reconsituting land that had been raped of its natural resources.

reviews.title: Peaceful In The City
text: Although the Brick Works confused me a little bit (due to the mixture of apparent functions), it was a very pleasant place to visit and have lunch. I did feel that there could be more information provided about the history and current use of the spaces, but I enjoyed seeing the old brick ovens and the stroll around the pond was a lovely end to our visit.

text: We visited for a couple of hours late in the day when the centre was closing. We enjoyed a peaceful walk seeing the flora and fauna - especially pleased to see the turtles

reviews.title: Evergreen Brick Works park & markets
text: Such a lovely place to visit and to spend part or entire day. Lot of fun to do: walking through little pathways surrounded with the beautiful trees, flowers, places to sit and rest, read, meditate or just be. There are three ponds with lot of surprises for kids to discover and to have fun. There is farmer market on Saturdays, other days they have arts, clothing, jewelry, so much to see and to enjoy, including food and drinks all kind, Cafe & a restaurant. Living in the busy & noisy city this was a wonderful discovery!

reviews.title: Sunday Afternoon at the Market
text: I finally made time this past weekend to check out the Artisan Market at Evergreen Brickworks. It was a beautiful, sunny day, perfect to spend a couple of hours touring around the market & soaking up the sun.
This weekend, the market featured a Wild Blueberry Festival, so we got to try some delicious blueberry creations from local vendors, including blueberry ice pops and blueberry toasties. Very tasty!
Looking forward to going back again to see the farmersâ€™ market on a Saturday.

reviews.title: A TRANQUIL PLACE IN THE NOISY CITY
text: It is as the name suggests, it was a brick kiln in its hey days  which has been renovated to fit in a nature setting.

A beautiful tranquil community place in the city to relax. One sit by a pond or walk around the nature trails. The original brick kiln  building has a cafÃ© and store, water fountains, and washrooms. There is a Farmerâ€™s market on the weekend,
Perfect for families and nature lovers. Because it is surrounded by the city there are places where the one can see the Toronto skyline.
On the downside, Parking can be difficult though, because the parking spaces are limited.

reviews.title: The kids loved the natural playground
text: The adults loved the unique food options, however the fussy kids weren't so thrilled. Wish there had been some more kid-friendly options. Ice lollies were excellent!  Rice pudding was nice too.  We enjoyed the music while we ate, and my son wanted to give money to the musician. The kids loved the natural playground and spent hours building a fort with all the materials there. It gave us a chance to chat, so we were happy. We didn't get to hike as it was raining, but next time!

reviews.title: Return to an oasis in the city
text: In the early stages of the pandemic we went here often, and Sunday afternoon being very nice -- sunny and 15 -- we decided to pay the Brick Works another visit. The walks are nice, the fall colours are beautiful, and the views across the ponds are very pleasing. Unhappily we didn't reach the cafe until 4:05, when it had just closed. It should stay open until at least 5 pm.

reviews.title: Fantastic return to nature !
text: Try to visit on a market day â€¦. Plenty of parking on site. Dogs permitted on leash. Coffee and food available. Really nice to walk the board walks over the ponds and a short climb to the summit to see the best views of the location and the Toronto skyline. Enjoyable 2 - 3 hours

reviews.title: Like a Step into Toronto History
text: Great place to walk around and explore!  Located in the Don River valley - an escape from hi-rise concrete in downtown Toronto.

reviews.title: Return to nature
text: The first time I was here was in the mid-1960s, when I got bricks to use in making bookshelves. Since then it was abandoned, then reopened to become a combination shopping area (mostly on Saturdays) and a nature reserve, complete with a beaver pond. It's very enjoyable to explore, especially on a pleasant autumn afternoon.

reviews.title: An Enjoyable Day
text: This site was a contaminated brownfield - formerly a quarry and brickworks site. It has been transformed over the years to a series of wetlands, interconnected ponds, meadows, hiking/walking trails. We enjoyed a lovely day strolling around the area. Make sure that you go up to the lookout points (if you are able). The southern one gives you a nice view of the city and the CN Tower. The northern one gives you a nice overview of the site.

reviews.title: A quick nature fix in Toronto
text: If you are missing trees, and you don't have a day to get away, the Brickworks offer a quick fix. The cafe is nice, though public seating options could be improved in the main space. You can get a decent walk out of the surrounding nature. You may still hear cars, but it's better than nothing! And there are definitely still some wildlife sightings around there (I saw a snake the last time I was there!)

reviews.title: Great way to break up a day of shopping.
text: Perhaps the worlds smallest skating rink. I loved it. Very easy to get to, and reasonable parking rates. Great for a quick 15-30 min skate to break up a day downtown Toronto. Skates can be rented if needed, but bring your own if youâ€™ve got them. Thereâ€™s a cafe onsite, and what appeared to be a bar although it was closed on the Sunday afternoon that we visited.
